text:
after running this code
```# MODULE process for model
@load LogisticClassifier pkg=MLJLinearModels
clf = LogisticClassifier()
r_lambda = range(clf, :lambda, lower = 0.01, upper = 10.0, scale = :linear)
r_penalty = range(clf, :penalty, values = [:l1, :l2])
tuning = Grid(resolution = 10, rng = rng)

self_tuning_model = TunedModel(model = clf,
                               range = [r_lambda, r_penalty],
                               tuning = tuning,
                               resampling = CV(nfolds = 6, rng = rng),
                               measure = cross_entropy)
self_tuning_mach = machine(self_tuning_model, train_features, train_labels)
fit!(self_tuning_mach)
best_model = fitted_params(self_tuning_mach).best_model
best_mach  = machine(best_model, train_features, train_labels)

evaluate!(best_mach,
          resampling = CV(nfolds = 6, rng = rng),
          measure = [cross_entropy, area_under_curve])```
I was told that
>  
> Warning: Proximal GD did not converge in 1000 iterations.
what does this warning mean ?

elements.text:
# MODULE process for model
@load LogisticClassifier pkg=MLJLinearModels
clf = LogisticClassifier()
r_lambda = range(clf, :lambda, lower = 0.01, upper = 10.0, scale = :linear)
r_penalty = range(clf, :penalty, values = [:l1, :l2])
tuning = Grid(resolution = 10, rng = rng)

self_tuning_model = TunedModel(model = clf,
                               range = [r_lambda, r_penalty],
                               tuning = tuning,
                               resampling = CV(nfolds = 6, rng = rng),
                               measure = cross_entropy)
self_tuning_mach = machine(self_tuning_model, train_features, train_labels)
fit!(self_tuning_mach)
best_model = fitted_params(self_tuning_mach).best_model
best_mach  = machine(best_model, train_features, train_labels)

evaluate!(best_mach,
          resampling = CV(nfolds = 6, rng = rng),
          measure = [cross_entropy, area_under_curve])
Warning: Proximal GD did not converge in 1000 iterations.

text: You can essentially ignore the warning (sklearn uses the same thing just doesn't show you the warning). One thing to be careful about is that the scaling of the penalty is *not* automatically adjusted for dataset size (unlike in sklearn where it's done by default i.e. scaled by `n` ). So likely your `l1` scaling factor for some of the range is inappropriate and the optimization method used to solve the underlying problem doesn't converge.
